subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Question
msgSnippet: I ve given some thought to your idea, which asks, of course, the most embarrassing question that sits in the middle of this group, like the proverbial elephant
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] Question
I've given some thought to your idea, which asks, of course, the most embarrassing question that sits in the middle of this group, like the proverbial elephant in the parlor:

Is anyone going to do anything about it?

Here's some random thoughts on the matter:

I'd like to point out, your idea is not totally new, since Teddy Roosevelt also thought that English spelling was a "damn mess", and tried to promote spellings such as "nite" and "tuf."  But even a man as bullish and Presidential as he couldn't get these ideas off the ground.

The linguist Mario Pei has the opposite approach to yours, and thought that spelling reform should have a more blitzkreig approach.  Yes, he said, there would be chaos, but, since the new generation of toddlers that started to learn to read under the revised system would have absolutely no trouble at all (learning being learning), the chaos would only last for a few years - maybe half a generation -  instead of a century. He said the adults opposing reform (as if there was some organized lobby!) always approached the problem from their point of view, not that of a child.

One side effect to your proposition:  what gets written in the transition time is going to look like a real tossed salad, and will appear as nothing but illiterate spelling to most of the planet.  And there is no greater snob than a spelling snob.

Shaw himself was adamant that his system use no symbols that could be mistaken for old-fashioned Latin typography.  (Except note the "O" that couldn't be stopped!)  In his quaint, Victorian way, he was concerned that using regular letters might create some embarassing and even obscene letter combinations! (One of the few times Shaw was a product of his times.)

I'd also like to point out that we Americans have been dragging our feet in adopting the metric system for over 100 years, and that reform seems almost a piece of cake compared with the inertia that would confront even the most rabid spelling reformer.

Some members of the Shavian group have no interest in reform, but see the alphabet as a practical way to to teach non-English speakers our tongue.  I know of a Cambodian fellow of 20 who, right now, is faced not only with learning to spell, but how to write Latin characters for the first time in his life.Talk about a learning curve!  Think how much easier it would be for him to start with a system that made sense, where the shapes were the sounds!  Then, maybe after a year, and speaking well, he could slowly transition into conventional orthography.

Still, if there ever was a time that spelling reform was practical, this would be it.  With computers able to transliterate any text in an instant, people could download the Sunday Times in any spelling they liked, and the cost to the Times of producing such alternative texts would be next to nothing!

Still, I admire your optimism.  All for now......



I've been doing a little doodling in my spare time.  Writing
a 'journal' of sorts in Quikscript, just my thoughts that I write a
few minutes before each of my classes start.  Also, I've developed a
script quite similar to Readspel, in fact, based largely on it.  If
some don't know what that is, it's a system of writing English using
most of the letters of the Latin alphabet, but applying the rule
of 'one letter per sound.'  I figure that a system like this would
ease the populous into spelling reform.  Thus, comes my question.

Does anyone here actually plan on DOING anything to try to reform
spelling?  If so, how do you plan to go about it?  An approach I'd
thought of, is to introduce it slowly and gradually.  For example,
differentiate between 'th' in "this" and 'th' in "thing."  Then,
maybe make 'ng' one letter.  And gradually, introduce a seperate
letter to write each of the consonant sounds that are usually written
with more than one (i.e. sh, ch, ng, th, dh).  Note that there would
be a small amount of time, a few months let's say, between each small
change, allowing the populous to grow accustomed to the changes. 
Then, as soon as the consonant sounds are all introduced as one
letter, leave that for a while, then introduce a single letter for
each of the vowel sounds.  I believe that it can actually BE DONE,
but that it would be much easier, and much more accepted, if it were
done slowly and gradually.  What do you think?
